TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Sandy, mixed Typic Dystrocryepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Bottle sandy loam - forest.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--2 to 1 inch; undecomposed organic material principally needles, bark, and twigs.
02--1 to 0 inch; partially decomposed organic material like that of the horizon above; very strongly acid.
A2--0 to 6 inches; light gray (10YR 7/2) sandy loam, light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) moist; weak very thick platy structure that parts to medium granules; soft, very friable, nonsticky, nonplastic; very strongly acid (pH 4.6); clear wavy boundary.  (2 to 10 inches thick)
B2--6 to 14 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) sandy loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky, nonplastic; few dark colored concretions; very strongly acid (pH 4.9); abrupt wavy boundary.  (0 to 32 inches thick)
C--14 to 26 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) loamy fine sand, pale brown (10YR 6/3) moist; single grained; loose; very strongly acid (pH 4.9); abrupt wavy boundary.  (0 to 32 inches thick)
R--26 to 40 inches; hard Dakota sandstone.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Grand County, Colorado; approximately SE 1/4 SW 1/4 of Sec. 3, T. 2 S., R. 76 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Very thin dark colored A1 horizons occur above the albic horizon in some pedons.  Base saturation ranges from 30 to 59 percent (NH4Ac).  Depth of the lithic contact ranges from 20 to 40 inches.  Depth to the base of the cambic horizon ranges from 8 to 24 inches.  The cambic horizon and upper part of the control section are typically sandy loam, but clay ranges from 4 to 18 percent, silt from 5 to 30 percent, and sand from 52 to 80 percent with more than 35 percent fine or coarser sand.  Textures coarser than loamy very fine sand are excluded from the above ranges.  The lower part of the control section is loamy sand or sand and is thick enough to predominate the control section so that on a weighted average basis the soil belongs in a sandy family.  Rock fragments range from 0 to 35 percent in a major part of the solum and any C horizon and these are mainly 1/2 to 10 inches in diameter.  A majority of subhorizons above the bedrock have hue of 7.5YR or yellower, although in some pedons subhorizons redder than 7.5YR occur.  These soils are dry in all parts of the moisture control section at some time in most years.
The A2 horizon has hue of 5 through 7.5YR, value of 5 through 8 dry, 4 through 7 moist, and chroma of 1 through 6.  It is very strongly acid or strongly acid (1:5 dilution unbuffered organic dye).
The B2 horizon has hue of 5Y through 5YR, value of 5 through 8 dry, 4 through 7 moist, and chroma of 1 through 6.  It is very strongly or strongly acid (1:5 dilution unbuffered organic dye).
The C horizon has hue of 5Y through 7.5YR.  It is strongly or very strongly acid (1:5 dilution unbuffered organic dye).

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Chromose, Goldhill, and Leal series.  Chromose soils have no bedrock above a depth of 40 inches and are more than 60 percent base saturated.  Goldhill and Leal soils have moderately coarse textured control sections.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Bottle soils are on gently to steeply sloping hills, ridges, and mountainsides.  Slopes typically range from about 2 to 40 percent or more.  The soil formed in moderately thin acid coarse textured materials weathered from sandstone bedrock.  At the type location the mean annual precipitation is about 26 inches with peak periods of precipitation in the spring and early summer months.  Mean annual temperature is 34 degrees F. and mean summer temperature is 46 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content:
GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Bobtail and Darling soils.  Bobtail soils are coarse-loamy and are more than 60 percent base
saturated in some part.  Darling soils average gravelly sandy loam in the control section and have a spodic horizon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well to excessively drained; slow to very slow runoff; rapid to very rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Used as grazing land, for recreation, and for timber production.  Native vegetation is spruce, fir, lodgepole pine, vaccinium, and snowberry.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Mountainous areas of central Colorado.  The series is of small extent.
